name: Mission Blue
text:
The Sargassum fish is an iconic resident of the Sargasso Sea Hope Spot. It typically floats along in sargassum, a large brown seaweed. Although it's capable of swimming, it often crawls through the Sargassum, using its pectoral fins like arms. 

Photo by Justin Lewis https://t.co/wUT7sEaorR

name: Mission Blue
text:
The Coral Triangle Hope Spot, in the western Pacific Ocean, has approximately 28,200 square miles of coral cover. These reefs support over 2,200 species of coral reef fish, more than 200 of which are found nowhere else on Earth.

Photo by Gregory Piper/Coral Reef Image Bank https://t.co/60GBQNPRo1

Wisdom, a Laysan albatross who is at least 69 years old, is the oldest known, banded bird in the wild. Over the past six decades, Wisdom continually migrates the Midway Atoll and has raised between 30-35 chicks. #WorldAlbatrossDay

Photo by Susan Middleton/USFWS https://t.co/lRP3YBidno

Green sea turtles have a circumglobal range. They are mainly herbivorous, feeding on seagrass and algae. Green sea turtles are an important part of seagrass ecosystems; seagrass beds grazed by turtles are healthier than ones that aren't.

name: Mission Blue
text:
This area includes Malpelo Island in Colombia & Cocos Island in Costa Rica. Together, these locations create the Golden Triangle, an area that is home to some of the sharkiest waters on Earth. #MBGal√°pagosExpedition

Photo by @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/hzFQ86SqEQ

name: Mission Blue
text:
The Gal√°pagos Islands are part of the Eastern Pacific Seascape Hope Spot, a massive area encompassing over 1 million square miles of biodiversity hotspots within the Eastern Pacific. #MBGal√°pagosExpedition

Photos by @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/URrC1HhMy6

name: Mission Blue
text:
Most turtle species experience temperature-dependent sex determination. Cooler nests tend to have more male hatchlings, while warmer nests tend to produce more females! #WorldTurtleDay 

Photo by Jesus Roldan, Ecodiversa, in the Choroni and Chuao Hope Spot https://t.co/iQad7MaE5M

name: Mission Blue
text:
There are 7 species of sea turtles, 6 of which can be found around the globe. Sea turtles travel between feeding and nesting grounds - sometimes traveling up to thousands of miles. #WorldTurtleDay 

Photo by @conserveturtles in the Bocas del Toro Hope Spot https://t.co/VWEVx7w55C

name: Mission Blue
text:
A big congratulations to the Hope Spot Champions, @CoralACenter! We'll be joining them tonight for a discussion of the Nusa Penida Marine Protected Area Hope Spot, starting at 6:30pm PDT. Sign up & get more info here: https://t.co/9MD14kOGGZ 

Photo by Marthen Welly https://t.co/hyGHnH0QIO

name: Mission Blue
text:
But the real beauty of the Nusa Penida Marine Protected Area Hope Spot is rooted in its people. Local residents participated in the planning of the MPA, and they champion reef and mangrove restoration programs on top of assisting with park management. 

Photo by Rili Djohani https://t.co/in01gmVPCr

name: Mission Blue
text:
The area is home to nearly 300 species of coral, over 500 species of reef fish, and two vulnerable species of manta - the oceanic manta and the reef manta.

Photo by Marthen Welly https://t.co/hVlwAyEZqG

name: Mission Blue
text:
Bearded seals are just one of the charismatic marine mammals that can be found in the Arctic. They are the largest species of Arctic seal, reaching lengths of 8 feet and weighing up to 800 pounds!

Photo by @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/oaiAHjmZO8

name: Mission Blue
text: Polar photographer @PaulNicklen shares his stories of wildlife in the Arctic and Antarctic. https://t.co/27uHODj60m #HopeSpots https://t.co/UDmJd91a60

name: Mission Blue
text: Polar bears are well adapted for life in the cold. Their big paws have specialized footpads that are covered in papillae, small bumps that help them grip the ice. Polar bear fur is a combo of insulating underfur & guard hairs. It prevents almost all heat loss when dry! https://t.co/gqx3H0CSjk

name: Mission Blue
text: When you think of sea ice, what kind of wildlife comes to mind? How about polar bears? Polar bears rely on sea ice for survival. text:

name: Mission Blue
text:
In 2016, the IUCN announced that we must take steps to protect 30% of the ocean - the blue heart of our planet - by 2030. #30x30

Photo by @KipEvansPhoto in the Monterey Bay Hope Spot https://t.co/R40h51bmsU

name: Mission Blue
text:
Today, only 5.3% of the world‚Äôs ocean is protected in implemented & actively managed marine protected areas. Approximately half of that, or 2.5%, of the ocean is highly protected in no-take marine reserves. #30x30

Photo by Michael Van Woert, NOAA taken in the Ross Sea Hope Spot https://t.co/PINUQU9Cnu

name: Mission Blue
text:
Research shows that fully protected, or ‚Äúno-take‚Äù (extraction of marine wildlife or resources is prohibited) marine protected areas provide the most benefit to the areas they cover. #30x30

Photo by @KipEvansPhoto, taken in Palau, part of the Micronesian Islands Hope Spot https://t.co/LZbfcswfMo

name: Mission Blue
text:
Marine protected areas are valuable tools for preserving and protecting natural ecosystems. These areas can be called sanctuaries, refuges, or reserves, and offer full or limited protection. #30x30

Photo from @OceanGeographic, taken in the Bunaken Marine Park Hope Spot https://t.co/9QCicE0hk2

name: Mission Blue
text:
Below, we have three images of whale flukes! Can you identify the ones that belong to humpback whales? #WhatTheFlukes

Photo by Whit Welles https://t.co/dqabforL1c

name: Mission Blue
text:
Humpback flukes are particularly unique. It's not uncommon to see a humpback raise their flukes out of the water as they prepare to dive. Humpback flukes are usually black (or dark grey) and white and have an uneven trailing edge.  

Photo by NOAA https://t.co/UMXnhJNuG1

name: Mission Blue
text:
A cetacean's tail is known as its flukes. Flukes have two separate lobes (each called a fluke) that meet in a v-shape. They can be used to identify different species of whales, and some researchers use this as a way to track individuals. 

Photo by Guille Pozzi https://t.co/OeHy9OfzRU

Puffins, like this one from the Argyll Coasts and Islands Hope Spot, spend most of the year out at sea. They return to the same breeding grounds year after year, maintaining burrows where they lay eggs and raise their young.

text: Here we have a mantis shrimp from the Coastal Waters of the Black River District Hope Spot. Stomatopods have unbelievably good vision - quite possibly the best in the animal kingdom. name: Mission Blue
text: First, how to tell seals and sea lions apart. Seals do not have an external ear flap. They have short front flippers and move on land by scooching on their bellies, or galumphing! https://t.co/HL6MHgdw15

name: Mission Blue
text: This week, you have sailed alongside as we explored Malpelo Island, its champions, the research, and challenges Malpelo Island and its wildlife face. Now is your chance to dive into the Malpelo Island Hope Spot quiz and test your new knowledge! #MalpeloExpedition2019 #HopeSpots https://t.co/HoVB4dXIXJ

name: Mission Blue
text:
Whale, hello! Whale sharks, such as this one that approached our boat, are highly migratory species. They are one of the species being tracked by Migramar to study their behavior and inform the policy that protects them. 

üé•: Brett Loveman

https://t.co/ghQWQ2IcNl

name: Mission Blue
text:
.@MigraMar and @FMalpelo are working together to understand the interconnectedness of shark populations within the Eastern Pacific Seascape, and how we can use this information to best protect sharks. #HopeSpots 

Media by @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/cFwWcFsKe8

name: Mission Blue
text: During the Malpelo Expedition, we were accompanied by Mauricio Hoyos and Cesar Pe√±aherrera, two of the foremost experts on sharks in the Eastern Tropical Pacific and scientists with @MigraMar. Read @SNich94's blog on their work! https://t.co/545o37QnUF #MalpeloExpedition2019 https://t.co/uuZGPJRedU

name: Mission Blue
text:
Combined with their ability to travel long distances and their inability to tell us about themselves using words, they can be tough subjects to study. To understand the best way to protect sharks, it is imperative to know as much as we can about them. 

üé•: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/q6R69zPmc4

name: Mission Blue
text:
Although they have a fearsome image, sharks (like the ones that inhabit the waters at Malpelo Island) tend to be timid and flighty. #MalpeloExpedition2019 #HopeSpots

üì∏: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/AcCmG3GIWN

name: Mission Blue
text:
We are continuing to learn more about these routes, and refer to these well-traveled pathways as migratory corridors or highways. As scientists learn about the habits of these ocean trekkers, they can pinpoint ways to better protect this traveling wildlife.

üì∏: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/XIJCTwIL0a

name: Mission Blue
text:
The sharks and rays we spotted at Malpelo Island do not always stay there. Whether for food or in search of a potential mate, they travel between locations within the Eastern Pacific Seascape and beyond. #MalpeloExpedition2019 #HopeSpots 

üé•: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/FKL0pGmnRP

name: Mission Blue
text: Dive into Ocean Stories to read about how individuals are stepping up to protect Malpelo's wildlife: https://t.co/ehth3LJyMF Stories by @Snich94, media by @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/njiKlJ2fnf

name: Mission Blue
text: Malpelo Island an example of both Colombia‚Äôs conservation successes and challenges. Despite being a no-take marine reserve, it is still threatened by illegal fishing. Its remote location makes the boundaries of the reserve challenging to enforce. #MalpeloExpedition2019 #HopeSpots https://t.co/Xe2EPfqTlQ

name: Mission Blue
text:
Depending on the location of the marine protected area, enforcing the boundaries may be challenging. The Malpelo Fauna and Flora Sanctuary is one of the largest no-fishing zones in the Eastern Tropical Pacific and still feels pressure from illegal fishing. 

üé•: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/Fql0xpAI9G

name: Mission Blue
text:
Even fully protected marine reserves - where it is illegal to extract any wildlife - face challenges from humans. These challenges may include pressure from plastic pollution, impacts from climate change, or the stress of illegal fishing and overfishing. 

üì∏: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/cku5hm1wke

name: Mission Blue
text:
These areas can be called sanctuaries, refuges, or reserves, and offer full or limited protection. Research demonstrates that fully protected, or ‚Äúno-take‚Äù marine protected areas provide the most conservation benefit to the areas they cover. 

üé•: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/EXwOfefuuA

name: Mission Blue
text:
Marine protected areas, like Malpelo Fauna and Flora Sanctuary, are valuable tools for preserving and protecting natural ecosystems. They can have many names, shapes, and sizes. #MalpeloExpedition2019 #HopeSpots

üì∏: @KipEvansPhoto https://t.co/m8EHreoq3B

There‚Äôs a range of marine life, from bright reef fish to turtles & sharks, including the endangered scalloped hammerhead.

#SAHopeSpots https://t.co/ePWjhP3Pe7

name: Mission Blue
text: RT @OceaniMPActSA: The fourth #SAHopeSpot we're celebrating is Knysna, which is unique because it‚Äôs the world‚Äôs first estuarine Hope Spot.‚Ä¶
retweet_text:
The fourth #SAHopeSpot we're celebrating is Knysna, which is unique because it‚Äôs the world‚Äôs first estuarine Hope Spot.

Due to the coexistence of both marine & endemic estuarine forms, a host of species occur here, including the Knysna Seahorse.

üì∏: Getty Images https://t.co/TXXMIZ3n1k

name: Mission Blue
text:
RT @OceaniMPActSA: The Cape Whale Coast is the third South African Hope Spot, which stretches 200kms from Rooi Els to Quoin Point.

Much of‚Ä¶
retweet_text:
The Cape Whale Coast is the third South African Hope Spot, which stretches 200kms from Rooi Els to Quoin Point.

Much of the area is already protected and is home to the Marine Big 5: whales, dolphins, sharks, seals and African penguins.

Image credit: @animalocean 

#SAHopeSpots https://t.co/w7i1whwmzB

name: Mission Blue
text:
RT @OceaniMPActSA: The second South African Hope Spot is Plettenberg Bay - one of SA‚Äôs richest areas in terms of biodiversity.

It incorpor‚Ä¶
retweet_text:
The second South African Hope Spot is Plettenberg Bay - one of SA‚Äôs richest areas in terms of biodiversity.

It incorporates Robberg Island, which is home to over 7000 Cape cormorants and the iconic humpback dolphin.

Image credit: @Plett_Tourism 

#SAHopeSpots https://t.co/3RlmH6LsJE

name: Mission Blue
text: RT @OceaniMPActSA: The Algoa Bay Hope Spot has migratory humpback and Southern right whales visiting in the winter months, with bottlenose‚Ä¶

The Algoa Bay Hope Spot has migratory humpback and Southern right whales visiting in the winter months, with bottlenose and common dolphins also regularly passing through. 

Pic credit: Steve Benjamin / @animalocean 

#SAHopeSpots #NationalMarineWeek https://t.co/M1yAmHjDfe

name: Mission Blue
text:
RT @OceaniMPActSA: The first SA Hope Spot for #NationalMarineWeek is Algoa Bay.

It was named a Hope Spot for its rich biodiversity. The St‚Ä¶
retweet_text:
The first SA Hope Spot for #NationalMarineWeek is Algoa Bay.

It was named a Hope Spot for its rich biodiversity. The St Croix Islands within Algoa Bay are home to the largest breeding colony of African penguins & the largest population of Cape gannets in the world.

#SAHopeSpots https://t.co/6m6EjVMgyA

text: The Eastern Pacific Seascape Hope Spot is home to all of the above and more. name: Mission Blue
text: Sylvia and her family moved to Dunedin on the Florida Gulf when she was 12. It was there she got to know the ocean and started her lifelong passion to study ocean wildlife!

name: Mission Blue
text: Sylvia has logged over 7,500 hours underwater! She led the first team of women aquanauts during the Tektite Project in 1970, and setting a record for solo diving in 1,000 meters depth.

name: Mission Blue
text: Sylvia majored in Botany at Florida State University. She went on to receive her Masters in Botany and PhD for her dissertation, 'Phaeophyta of the Eastern Gulf of Mexico'. She earned the nickname 'Seaweed Sylvia'!

name: Mission Blue
text: Mission Blue was started in 2009. We're celebrating 10 years and going for Sylvia's birthday - you can support our mission, here: https://t.co/oi1ZHlizFC

name: Mission Blue
text: Dr. @SylviaEarle's TED Prize wish was to "ignite public support for a network of global marine protected areas, hope spots large enough to save and restore the ocean, the blue heart of the planet." Presently, there are 116 Hope Spots and counting!

name: Mission Blue
text: Arctic Hope Spots, such as Spitsbergen and the Northwest Passage, and Antarctic Hope Spots, including the Ross Sea and the Antarctic Peninsula, provide opportunities to study and mitigate the impacts, as well as bring awareness to these remote locations. https://t.co/IfuN0g0Cpw

name: Mission Blue
text: The impact of melting glaciers reaches far beyond the poles, contributing to the increase in the average global sea of 4-8 inches in the past 100 years, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. https://t.co/OZKYSYCYIC

name: Mission Blue
text: These polar ecosystems also face similar threats from climate change, as warming temperatures are melting sea ice which is depended on by many animals including polar bears, walruses, and crabeater seals. https://t.co/tnFWZuXjTD

name: Mission Blue
text: This wildlife is specially adapted to thrive in some of the most extreme conditions on the planet. https://t.co/AI2mMyOmJl

name: Mission Blue
text: Though these ocean basins are polar opposites üòâ both of their landscapes are composed of various forms of ice and frigid, productive waters that support diverse ocean wildlife. https://t.co/Ynkesl8He0

name: Mission Blue
text: At the Northern and Southern-most ends of the Earth lie the polar ecosystems of the Arctic and Antarctic. #WorldOceansWeek https://t.co/6mAR1dSv8g

name: Mission Blue
text: "Diving into the ocean is like diving into the history of the Earth. There are plenty of reasons for optimism because there is so much we now know." @SylviaEarle speaks at the 'How To: Save the Oceans' conference at the @RGS_IBG. @howtoacademy #SaveOurOceans https://t.co/ede81Is3bP

name: Mission Blue
text: Kelp health is sensitive to pollution from sources like coastal runoff and sewage. Protecting coastal habitats can help keep kelp forests resilient. https://t.co/NxKmYjw2pu

name: Mission Blue
text: The False Bay and Monterey Bay Hope Spots are home to breathtaking kelp forests. https://t.co/M6jf3uw9Up

name: Mission Blue
text:
Macrocystis, or giant kelp, can grow upwards at a rate 10-20 inches a day to find sunlight. It stays anchored to rocky seafloors with a root structure known as a holdfast, which provides host to all sorts of invertebrates, like brittle stars and crabs.

üì∏: Claire Fackler, @NOAA https://t.co/EPCb9hOWws

name: Mission Blue
text: They provide habitat to top predators like white sharks, down to the smallest nudibranch. https://t.co/lh1US9HBzl

name: Mission Blue
text: There are beautiful kelps forests around the world, mostly in temperate and arctic waters. #WorldOceansWeek https://t.co/EGBTPv919W

name: Mission Blue
text: "...It is such a joy, like falling into the Fourth of July." https://t.co/N14vOHKx80

name: Mission Blue
text: "...because most of the creatures in the deep sea have some form of firefly-like kind of light, that bioluminescence, and as they brush up against the submersible that you're in, they just are provoked into these little sparkle-sparkle-sparkles..." https://t.co/kqSXSJAiAv

name: Mission Blue
text: "...It's just gray and then black. And it's dark; yet it isn't really dark. It's filled with light. There are little sparkle, flashes and glows all around you, like--it's like falling into a galaxy of little stars..." https://t.co/3rqmOZiMy8

name: Mission Blue
text: "Penetrating through that green [in the Gulf of Mexico] and then break into clear blue water below and then it gets darker as you descend into indigo and then almost a purply-blue, and then not blue at all...." https://t.co/HjH69QeFae

name: Mission Blue
text:
.@SylviaEarle's deepest dive on record is an astonishing 2.5 miles down. That's beyond the reaches of sunlight, where wildlife creates its own light. She describes what it's like to descend into the deep sea in the Gulf of Mexico Hope Spot...

üì∏:Dr. Ian MacDonald, @floridastate https://t.co/Caz3kKjsCV

name: Mission Blue
text:
Help us protect the deep sea, these important and vulnerable ecosystems, by supporting policy that protects deep sea habitats and wildlife from exploitation and encouraging others to do so as well!

üì∏: Yellow Picasso Sponges at the Davidson Seamount, taken by @NOAA/@MBARI_News https://t.co/a5cA8tBDOt

name: Mission Blue
text:
We've only just begun to explore the seamounts, and already the deep sea is vulnerable to exploitation through seabed mining and drilling. 

üì∏: Unknown cnidarian at the Davidson Seamount, taken by @NOAA/@MBARI_News https://t.co/bbRPiwe6Tv

name: Mission Blue
text:
Seamounts are important for the deep sea, and influence productivity in the ocean at all levels.

üì∏:  Dandelion siphonophore, taken by NOAA @oceanexplorer https://t.co/efazm48Lf6

name: Mission Blue
text:
One of our newest Hope Spots, the California Seamounts, highlights the 60 seamounts found just offshore in California waters. Of these 60, only one seamount is strongly protected. https://t.co/lOzFaB0mXF

üì∏: Benthic octopus at the Davidson Seamount, taken by @NOAA/@MBARI_News https://t.co/y4RV8a4mu7

name: Mission Blue
text:
The deep sea is home to wildlife like 10,000 year old sponge reefs, 4,000 year old solitary corals, and fish like orange roughy that may live to be over 150 years old. 

üì∏: Bubblegum coral at the Davidson Seamount, taken by @NOAA/@MBARI_News https://t.co/C7C5rCNJuv

name: Mission Blue
text:
Very little is known about deep sea ecosystems. We understand less about the deep sea than we do about space! #WorldOceansWeek 

üì∏: A hydromedusa in Mona Canyon, taken by NOAA @oceanexplorer https://t.co/ZNCeSM6FOX

name: Mission Blue
text: When water temperatures get too hot for the zooxanthellae, they hit the alarm button and bail from the coral. This causes the coral to become white, a condition called bleaching. If corals go too long without support from zooxanthellae, they may die. https://t.co/uuS7scEIGx

name: Mission Blue
text:

text: Community stakeholders, NGOs, dive shops, educational institutions and government agencies all pulled together to create and make these important changes happen!

name: Mission Blue
text: Read more about these important steps here: https://t.co/pmAwNDOR2h

name: Mission Blue
text: Blue Heron Bridge is in Phil Foster Park in Palm Beach County, FL. It's a world-renowned dive site and home to longsnout seahorses, polka-dot batfish, frogfish and species of blennies that can only be found in a few worldwide locations.

name: Mission Blue
text: @myFWC also agreed to put protection measures in place for a high-quality snorkeling and diving area called Blue Heron Bridge, by prohibiting the collection of fish species in this area for the tropical aquarium trade.

name: Mission Blue
text: The new regulations have a number of other benefits too, head here: https://t.co/gz848aovIK to learn more! It's a big step in the right direction!

name: Mission Blue
text: Measures have been put into place by @MyFWC to try to reduce shark mortality. Sharks like great hammerheads and tiger sharks are extremely susceptible to death during and after catch and release fishing.

name: Mission Blue
text: Shore-based shark fishing has long been an issue in Southeast Florida and now sharks will have a bit more of a fighting chance! Species such as great hammerheads and tiger sharks have been dying due to poor handling during shore-based fishing activities.

name: Mission Blue
text: üö®üö® BREAKING NEWS from our Coastal Southeast Florida Hope Spot Champion @SharkTeamOne! In a double win today, @myFWC voted to increased protections for sharks and marine ornamental fish. #HopeSpots https://t.co/wp7N80O1pc

name: Mission Blue
text: "I‚Äôve been a fisherman my whole life...We did it because our parents did that‚Ä¶they made nets and fished. That was my life and I‚Äôve been fishing ever since. We used to go for anything we could get, but now we have rules." https://t.co/f99E6moP2L #HopeSpots https://t.co/7pDacAI9zV

name: Mission Blue
text: We're buoyed with confidence that substantial progress has been made to lay the groundwork for marine protected areas! ü¶à

name: Mission Blue
text: The Expedition Team also dove in Cabo Pulmo National Marine Park to see the success of this marine protected area, and then engaged with stakeholders at the 2nd annual Shark Conference in La Paz, put together by @PelagiosKakunja.

name: Mission Blue
text: The Expedition Team visited rural communities in Baja California Sur, Mexico in order to document and better understand the lives of shark fishermen, the economics of shark fishing and viable strategies for transitioning away from these extractive activities. #WorthMoreAlive

Beneath this turbulent ocean
my polyps seem stony, slow to emotion.
But glance at this spectacle, 
as I extend every tentacle.
Millimeters, just enough
for a kiss, or a touch.
Sharing the joy of this tropical reef.
--

name: Mission Blue
text: It's home to rich marine biodiversity and biomass, including migrating seabirds, reptiles, mammals and fish, who are reliant on the healthy coral reef, sea grass beds, coral sandy cays, mangrove and open ocean ecosystems.

name: Mission Blue
text: It has been protected from destructive and irresponsible tourism practices, pollution from unsustainable coastal development, and severe habitat degradation from overfishing since 1996.

text:
The Atlantis Bank Hope Spot is a tectonic seamount on the southwest Indian Ridge. It is home to populations of large octocorals and sponges including the Venus basket sponge. #HopeSpots #WorldOceansWeek
